comments:
Build ID: I20070621-1340

Steps To Reproduce:
1.  hide .project and if any preferences changes are made that are stored in .project like renaming project it fails.
2.
3.


More information:

Richard, can you please provide step-by-step instructions? I never see the .project file in my Package Explorer but don't encounter this issue...
(In reply to comment #1)
> Richard, can you please provide step-by-step instructions? I never see the
> .project file in my Package Explorer but don't encounter this issue...

I am using Eclipse and CDT bundled together.  

Just create a cdt project with a different tool chain.

Outside of Eclipse hide the file .project.

Inside of eclipse try to rename the project.
It will fail.  I assume it fails, because it can't write to the .project file.  The name of the project is stored in .project and it doesn't change even though the folder and the name in the navigation window do change.

unhide the .project file and rename will then work.

The same applies with the .cdtproject file from CDT 3.0, but still using CDT 4.0.
I haven't tested the .cproject file used in CDT 4.0.

This is a generic issue (I.e. I can do it quite simply without CDT)...taking it back.
(In reply to comment #2)
> [... snip ...]
> 
> Outside of Eclipse hide the file .project.

What does "hide" mean in this context?  Did you move it to another directory/temporarily rename it?

PW

(In reply to comment #4)
> (In reply to comment #2)
> > [... snip ...]
> > 
> > Outside of Eclipse hide the file .project.
> What does "hide" mean in this context?  Did you move it to another
> directory/temporarily rename it?
> PW
Hide is to set the file attribute to hidden!
(In reply to comment #5)
> Hide is to set the file attribute to hidden!
> 

If hiding the file makes it not show up, then it seems to me it won't work.  This Hidden attribute sounds like a windows thing.

PW
(In reply to comment #6)
> (In reply to comment #5)
> > Hide is to set the file attribute to hidden!
> > 
> If hiding the file makes it not show up, then it seems to me it won't work. 
> This Hidden attribute sounds like a windows thing.
> PW

The file is still shown in the navigator view even when hidden.
If it is hidden it should still be writable!
If this is a problem then eclipse should always make these file unhidden in windows.
(In reply to comment #7)
> If it is hidden it should still be writable!

Maybe I don't understand ... when you say it fails, do you mean it pops up a dialog that says "file not found"?  Does it enter an error in the error log? <workspace>/.metadata/.log

> If this is a problem then eclipse should always make these file unhidden in
> windows.

Why would we?  That's a windows only attribute ... and the workaround is, don't set it.

Szymon, this seems like a Core Resources/Filesystem issue.

PW

(In reply to comment #8)
> (In reply to comment #7)
> > If it is hidden it should still be writable!
> Maybe I don't understand ... when you say it fails, do you mean it pops up a
> dialog that says "file not found"?  Does it enter an error in the error log?
> <workspace>/.metadata/.log
> > If this is a problem then eclipse should always make these file unhidden in
> > windows.
> Why would we?  That's a windows only attribute ... and the workaround is, don't
> set it.
> Szymon, this seems like a Core Resources/Filesystem issue.
> PW

Our projects are stored on a sun server and when I import a project from the server the dot files like .project and .cproject are allows made hidden.
When these files are hidden not changes can be made to the properties or renmaing.
As a workaround I have made a plugin to create a extra property page to be able to set the hidden attribute inside eclipse.
Maybe this can be set in the import fuction to make the files unhidden.
Created an attachment (id=73987)
Pop up after trying to rename with .project file hidden!

Log file for this same rename fault!

Taken from the windows help and support center:

 Notes

Hidden files and folders will appear dimmed to indicate they are not typical items. Usually, hidden files are program or system files that should not be deleted or changed. To display other hidden files, clear the Hide protected operating system files (Recommended) check box. 
If you know the name of a hidden file or folder, you can search for it. For more information, click Related Topics. 
If you want to see all file name extensions, clear the Hide file extensions for known file types check box. 

My comments:
Hidden files should only be removed from the users view.  It should not make the file read only and it should still make the files accessable if the name is known.
The readonly attribute will make the file undeletable or unwritable.
